newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai copper futures end down on LME losses.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai copper futures end down on LME losses.

text.p: Shanghai copper futures ended down on Friday, with most contracts closing below the key 20,000-yuan level due to overnight losses on the London Metal Exchange, traders said.
The most active March 1997 contract ended at 19,900 yuan ($2,397) per tonne, down 260 yuan. It opened at an intra-day high of 20,000 and hit a low of 19,880.
December fell 200 to 19,950, January 220 to 19,890, February 230 to 18,890, April 250 to 19,900, May 270 to 19,910 and June 300 to 20,000.
Combined volume fell to 76,400 tonnes from 76,790.
Copper opened lower and fell further with most contracts closing at or near their intra-day lows.
Traders said speculative selling and bearish expectations, triggered by the LME losses, pushed most contracts below the 20,000-yuan level.
"Expectations of rises of LME stockpiles hurt confidence of long position holders, with a bout of panic selling in the morning session," one trader said.
"Copper fell below 20,000 yuan again, indicating that most investors were not optimistic about the future trend," he added.
Traders said copper would fall further if it cannot recover its losses next Monday.
"It is very important for long and short position holders to see whether or not copper can hold above the 20,000-yuan level," a second trader said.
Aluminium ended mostly up. December fell 10 to 13,680, January rose 60 to 13,910 and February rose 50 to 14,050.
